Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Laura R. Stein
Proposal Number: 1611874

This award funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Broadening Participation of Groups Underrepresented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Laura R. Stein is "Synthesizing mechanistic and functional explanations for the role of maternal effects in adaptation." The host institution for this fellowship is Colorado State University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Kim Hoke.

This fellowship research assesses the causes and consequences of maternal effects, using Trinidadian guppies (Poecilia reticulata) as a model organism and incorporating behavioral, hormonal, neurobiological, and genomic approaches. Previous research shows that experiences early in life (or as an embryo) can shape the development of morphology, physiology, and behavior of the organisms, and can facilitate adaptive evolution if these experiences help individuals survive in novel environments. Individuals receive information about their environment via their evolutionary history (genetics), their own experiences, and from their parents (parental effects). While existing theory describes how individuals should integrate these sometimes conflicting sources of information, few experimental tests exist to determine the extent to which individuals use different cues to arrive at different developmental outcomes and whether these outcomes enhance survival and reproduction. The Fellow's research will be one of the few studies to bridge neurobiological and behavioral ecological fields to develop a holistic view of the development of behavior from micro to macro levels. Understanding how organisms integrate information at multiple levels (genetic, parental experience, and their own experience) is crucial for understanding how the environment plays a role in evolutionary patterns. This project is developing a rigorous and integrative framework that will inform understanding about maternal effects as a generator of variation in evolutionary processes.

The Fellow is developing resources for STEM education at low-income schools in northern Colorado. These schools do not currently have STEM programs, and the majority of students are from groups underrepresented in STEM fields. In collaboration with district teachers, the Fellow is developing a hands-on component to their new STEM program and building upon existing programs, utilizing guppies as a resource for teaching about the scientific method, ecology, and evolution. To further refine her teaching skills, the Fellow is holding training workshops for graduate students on public communication and outreach, culminating in presentations at the schools and establishing lasting ties between the schools and Colorado State University, the host institution. This work is providing students from underrepresented groups with role models representing scientists of different backgrounds and paths to science careers, and with exposure to scientific inquiry that would otherwise be unavailable. Finally, while women are now well-represented in the life sciences through graduate school, attrition rates remain high at the postdoctoral stage. In collaboration with social scientists and STEM educators, the Fellow is evaluating two approaches aimed at reducing imposter syndrome by creating two types of peer-mentoring clusters for female faculty, postdocs, and graduate students. Assessments are being used to tailor the program for future years to provide a reproducible framework that can be implemented across departments and institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Diverse literatures in ecology, evolutionary biology, and neuroscience have converged on the result that phenotypes reflect genetics, the environment, and their interaction, but until recently we have lacked a framework to explain why, from an evolutionary perspective, animals in some cases rely more on information from their ancestors, parents, or their own experience. New evolutionary theory proposes that natural selection favors the evolution of mechanisms that allow information to be integrated together and weighed according to their predictive ability. 

Here we address this question in the Trinidadian guppy (Poecilia reticulata), a well-studied system in ecology and evolution. Predation pressure shapes morphological and behavioral phenotypes in guppies in repeatable, parallel ways both genetically and plastically. Therefore the guppy system provides an ecological context in which to interpret the adaptive significance of maternal effects and personal experience.

We used a fully-factorial study design wherein females from multiple populations were either raised with olfactory predator cues or raised without cues.  Offspring were then split and raised either with or without predator cues. We found that offspring of predator-exposed mothers grow up to have morphological and behavioral phenotypes associated with living under strong predation pressure, and that personal and maternal experiences showed complex interactions depending on phenotype and offspring sex.  

Our studies show that maternal exposure to predator cues can influence guppy phenotypes as strongly as developmental exposure. Further, we found interactions between maternal and offspring experience for the majority of phenotypes tested, although some interactions differed based on sex and phenotype. Across taxa, sex differences in responsiveness to maternal effects are common. Sex-specific differences in response to environment suggest differences in developmental pathways and life histories may impact information integration across time scales. Finally, our study highlights the importance of measuring multiple phenotypes across sexes and developmental trajectories to enhance our understanding of how organisms integrate information across development and inform future theoretical work.

In addition to the main project, we have also conducted a series of studies examining how personal experience with reproduction influences male brain and behavior. We have found that one instance of reproduction changes behavior in exploratory, anti-predator, and aggression contexts for up to three days. Further, we have found that some aspects of aggressive behavior that are also associated with courtship remain changed for up to seven days, suggesting that reproduction may alter behavior in other contexts over the long-term. In addition, we have found changes in neural activity in response to predation risk associated with reproduction.

Over the course of this project, we developed hands-on outreach activites for grades 5 - 10. Using the guppy system, our activites address concepts of natural history, genetics, evolution, neuroscience, and behavioral ecology. In collaboration with the Pinhead Institute in Telluride, CO, we traveled to rural schools and gave demonstrations on these concepts. In addition, we performed public workshops at local libraries and parks. We have provided Pinhead with materials to distribute to local teachers to incorporate into their curriculum. Finally, we have begun to develop a mentoring network for women in the early stages of their careers in biology.
